passages.text: August 29, 2025 05:00 AM GMT

We alter our outlook for monetary policy in favor of 50bp in rate cuts this year and 100bp in 2026 for a terminal target range of 2.75- 3.0%. The Fed sees downside risk to labor markets as warranting less monetary restriction. Activity data suggest the economy has cooled, but remains resilient.

- Weak July payrolls mean the Fed will likely reduce its policy rate by 25bp in September and 50bp by year-end. Powell said the policy stance warrants adjusting.- Q2 US GDP was revised higher to \(3.3\%\) q/q saar on strong private consumption and business spending. Still, the economy has cooled in 1H 25 versus 2024.- GDI was boosted by tariff revenue, which did not appear to be offset by less income or profits elsewhere.- We make modest revisions to the US outlook in favor of slightly stronger growth, a lower peak unemployment rate, and firmer inflation in 2026.- Earlier Fed easing should reduce downside risk. Upside risks are driven by a greater fiscal push, animal spirits, and inflation tolerance.
Exhibit 1: We now expect quarterly rate cuts beginning in September for a terminal target range of 2.75- 3.0% by end- 2026.
Source, Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

Following Fed Chair Powell's remarks at Jackson Hole last week, we have changed our outlook for monetary policy to include two- 25bp rate cuts this year in September and December. In 2026, we think our outlook for the economy would justify four additional 25bp rate cuts in March, June, September, and December, for a terminal target range of 2.75- 3.0%. Previously, we expected the Fed to remain on hold until 2026, then deliver rate cuts at consecutive meetings from March onward to a terminal target range of 2.50- 2.75%. Hence, our revised path for monetary policy has one fewer rate cut than before. A Fed that cuts earlier may have to cut less.
Exhibit 2: Morgan Stanley US Economics Revised path for monetary policy in 2025- 26
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

The main reason for the change is due to a shift in the Fed's reaction function which has put greater weight on downside risk to the labor market following July's employment report that came with 258k in downward revisions to the prior two months of payrolls. The threemonth average change in payrolls downshifted to only 35k at the headline and 52k for private payrolls. Prior to this report, most FOMC participants felt risks to the dual mandate were skewed in the direction of inflation persistence, which was a key element in our no-cut outlook this year. However, at Jackson Hole, Chair Powell made it clear that the July employment report increased the committee's concern about weak labor demand. In addition, he noted that growth in real GDP indicated the economy was cooling. Finally, he noted that changes in trade and immigration policies have made it more difficult to distinguish between cyclical and structural effects in labor markets. Since monetary policy can only influence the former, it complicates the Fed's task.
"With policy in restrictive territory," he concluded, "the baseline outlook and the shifting balance of risks may warrant adjusting our

policy stance." Hence, the Fed appears ready to cut its policy rate at the September meeting. However, we do not think the Fed is leaning in the direction of a larger 50bp cut (unless the August employment report brings outright job losses). After all, Powell said, "our policy rate is now 100 basis points closer to neutral than it was a year ago, and the stability of the unemployment rate and other labor market measures allows us to proceed carefully as we consider changes to our policy stance." The phrase "proceed carefully" suggests the Fed is not ready to begin with another large up- front rate cut, as was the case in 2024, and it is not ready to reduce its policy rate at each of the three remaining meetings this year.
Source: BEA, Haver Analytics, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 4: Swings in net trade and inventories continue to disrupt the GDP picture
Source: BEA, Haver Analytics Morgan Stanley Research

The second estimate of Q2 US GDP saw growth revised higher to \(3.3\%\) q/q saar from \(3.0\%\) in the advance estimate a month ago. The main source of the upward revision came from private consumption, with is now reported as growing by \(1.6\%\) in the quarter on modestly stronger spending on services and nondurable goods. Elsewhere, nonresidential business fixed investment saw substantial upward revisions to intellectual property (+12.8% q/q saar versus \(6.4\%\) previously) and equipment (now \(7.4\%\) , up from \(4.8\%\) ), while structures was revised to show a smaller contraction (now \(- 8.9\%\) , from - 10.3). Not surprisingly, upward revisions to final sales came with modest downward revisions to inventory accumulation. On net, this pushed growth higher.

The second estimate also brings the first look at growth in gross domestic income, which grew at a rapid \(4.8\%\) annualized rate in the quarter in real terms. If there are persistent differences between GDP and GDI, as there have been during the COVID pandemic, we normally recommend averaging GDP and GDI to get a better picture of where the economy is at any
Exhibit 5: GDI was boosted by public sector tariff revenues without visible offsets elsewhere
Source: IEA, Haver Analytics, Morgan Stanley Research

point in time. However, in the second quarter, GDI was boosted mainly from a sharp increase in taxes on production and imports of \(\) 197.5b n\(in nominal terms), which accounted for\) 40\% \(of the total increase in GDI. We think this reflects tariff revenue increases at the federal level. In theory, this should be offset via less income for the private sector, but the data do not show any obvious offset. Hence, we think volatility in trade policies continues to distort quarterly readings of activity data that may only work themselves out over time. In short, we do not read the GDI data as suggesting the economy is accelerating.

Overall, the NIPA revisions do not alter our view of a moderating economy. Final sales to domestic purchasers (GDP less trade and inventories) rose at about a \(1.5\%\) annualized rate in 1H 25 after increasing \(3.0\%\) in 2024. The slowdown has been led by softer private consumption, residential investment, and federal spending. Business spending has generally held up, but disentangling frontloading effects from tariffs from other cyclical forces remains difficult. We read the data as consistent with our long- held view that restrictive trade and immigration policies would more than offset any boost from fiscal and deregulation.

With the details of the second estimate in hand and our revised path for monetary policy which brings slightly more front- loaded easing in our outlook than we had before, we make modest adjustments to our baseline outlook for the US economy in 2025- 26. We project growth in real GDP of \(1.1\% Q4 / Q4\) in 2025 and \(1.3\%\) in 2026, up one- and twotenths respectively. In turn, we revise our peak unemployment rate a tenth lower to \(4.8\%\) reached in the second half of 2026. Our forecast for GDP growth lies slightly below our estimate of potential this year and next, which should eventually push the unemployment rate modestly higher. Finally, a Fed that cuts rates for risk management reasons is exhibiting greater tolerance for inflation, and we now forecast headline and core PCE
inflation of \(3.0\%\) and \(3.2\%\) this year (Q4/Q4) and \(2.3\%\) and \(2.4\%\) next year. The latter is a tenth higher than our previous forecasts.

Our forecast continues to assume that much of the tariff pass through to consumer price inflation occurs in 2025. As a result, our weakest quarters for growth in activity are in Q4 of this year and Q1 of next year, and our peak impulse to inflation takes place in Q3 of this year at \(3.5\%\) q/q annualized. The incoming data on inflation and public remarks by businesses taking decisions on pricing point to a more elongated process. We think one of the main risks to our forecast for the US economy is a delayed pass through from tariffs that keeps inflation well above the Fed's \(2.0\%\) target for longer in 2026 than we currently anticipate.

We also update our alternative paths for the US economy (see Exhibit 23). Due to an earlier onset to policy rate easing from the Fed, we reduce the likelihood of a downturn in the economy to \(30\%\) and increase our no- recession baseline outlook to \(50\%\) . In a mild recession driven by trade restrictions, we think the Fed could ease to 150- 175% in 2026, though we think the policy rate can stay off the zero lower bound and QE will not be needed. We maintain an upside scenario built around greater fiscal expansion from the OBBBA than we expect and the animal spirits that could come with it. Should this materialize, then demand- side price pressures could mean the Fed eases this year but stays on hold in 2026 as inflation stays elevated (e.g. diminishes only slowly versus our baseline expectation). Our second upside scenario includes both animal spirits and a Fed policy reaction function that exhibits greater tolerance for above- target inflation. In this scenario, growth accelerates in 2026, the unemployment rate falls back toward post- COVID lows and inflation remains near \(3.0\%\) . Five- plus years of above- target inflation could cause inflation expectations to shift higher.

The Trump administration imposed additional tariffs on trading partners as of August 7 that pushed the effective tariff rate higher to \(16.0\%\) . Negotiations with three of the US's largest trading partners - Mexico, Canada, and China - are proceeding on a separate track. In addition, Section 232 reviews on trade in semiconductors, lumber, and pharmaceuticals, among others, remain ongoing.
Tariff receipts by the US Treasury continue to rise, with the rolling 63- day annualized customs and excise deposits at the Treasury rising to \(\) 355.8bn\$
Exhibit 6: US effective tariff rate
Source:US Census,US HTS,USITC,Morgan Stanley Research estimates
Exhibit 7: US Treasury: Customs and excise deposits from tariffs
Source:US Treasury, Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

Volatility in trade flows continue. Real imports surged \(37.9\%\) in Q1 2025 on front- loading effects ahead of tariffs. The Q2 GDP data show this process reversed in the second quarter, with real imports falling \(29.8\%\) . US export growth also declined, indicative of weaker global demand for US exports or a deceleration in trade in intermediate goods.

July and August data on container traffic suggest weak trade volumes have persisted into the third quarter. Here we show total daily shipping to the US (in millions of TEUs) and weighted average capacity of shipping into the US. Below we also show container volumes from China to the US in millions of TEUs, number of ships sailing from China to the US, and capacity.
Exhibit 8: Shipping volumes into US
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 9: Capacity of shipping into US
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 10: Container volumes from China
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 11: Vessels sailing from China
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

Housing starts and new home sales were close to our estimates for July and did not change our 3Q GDP tracking. However, strong capital goods shipments and inventory investment in the July durables goods report bumped up our estimate to \(1.2\%\) from \(1.1\%\) . The greater strength reflects inventory investment. For now, we are waiting for trade data to supplement capital goods shipments strength before updating our estimate of equipment investment.

In addition, GDP revisions amplified earlier strength in intellectual property investment. We now expect that investment stalls in 3Q rather than declining, adding another tenth to our GDP estimate and raising it to \(1.3\%\)

Our estimate for GDP has a sharp slowdown in August and September as tariffs diminish consumer purchasing power. It depends on faster inflation in August and September. We see several upside risks. Tariff effects on activity could be smaller than we expect. Their effects on prices could be delayed, strung out over more months, resulting in a smaller but more prolonged effect on real consumption. There also could be a boost to consumption from pulled forward demand for autos ahead of the expiration of EV tax credits. Downside risks come from tariffs, prices, uncertainty, and the possibility of faster deterioration in the labor market.

The Atlanta Fed GDP nowcast slipped a tenth to \(2.2\%\) . They do not build in the sharp slowing in consumer spending that we expect and have 3Q consumption at \(2.2\%\) vs. our \(0.7\%\) . The NY Fed measure has hovered just above \(2\%\) . For a comparison of the trackers, please see "How GDP trackers stack up".
Exhibit 12: The effect of incoming data on our US GDP tracking estimate
DateDetails of 3Q 2025 US GDP tracking (% in Q4 year unless indicated)
Exhibit 13: NY Fed, Atlanta Fed, and Morgan Stanley 3Q GDP tracking
Source:NY Fed,Atlanta Fed,Morgan Stanley Research

Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research forecasts

Factory surveys. The S&P manufacturing PMI jumped to 53.3 in the preliminary reading for August. We expect the ISM measure, rises 1.0 point to 49.0, to a level very close to the average so far this year. Over the same period, manufacturing output has risen an average of \(0.2\%\) per month.
Construction spending. We expect that single-family homebuilding again weighed on construction, pulling it to a \(0.2\%\) decline. The report also shows net declines in business
structures spending so far this year, which we expect continue into 3Q, notwithstanding growth in Al-related powerplant investment and data centers.
Exhibit 17: Wednesday

Wednesday 03 SeptDataPeriodForecastConsensusPrev7:00 AMWards Total Vehicle SalesAug16.016.016.49:00 AMMBA Mortgage Applications29-Aug-0.510:00 AMFed's Musalem Speaks on Economy and Policy at Peterson0-Jan10:00 AMJOLTS Job OpeningsJul74372:00 PMFactory OrdersJul-1.3-1.4-4.8Fed Releases Beige Book
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research forecasts

Motor vehicle sales. We expect some slight slowing, from a 16.4 million unit annual rate in July to a 16.0 million unit pace in August. Some demand is probably being pulled forward by the expiration of EV tax credits at the end of September.

Job openings and labor turnover (JOLTS). Private- sector job openings, hiring and layoff rates all slipped slightly last month but were unchanged from a year earlier. Notwithstanding the slowing in payrolls, they have not indicated increased slack. Maybe with this report for July, they will—it was the July employment report that showed sharp downward revision to 2Q.

Beige Book. The Beige Book has not been a particularly useful indicator of activity in recent years, consistently suggesting weaker growth than occurred. Still, any hint it offers on firm behavior around tariffs could be useful.
Exhibit 18: Thursday

Thursday 04 SeptDataPeriodForecastConsensusPrev7:30 AMChallenger Job Cuts y/yAug139.88:15 AMADP Employment ChangeAug701048:30 AMNonfarm Productivity2Q F3.22.48:30 AMUnit Labor Costs2Q F0.91.68:30 AMInitial Jobless Claims30-Aug2302298:30 AMContinuing Claims23-Aug195019548:30 AMTrade BalanceJul-73.0-62.6-60.29:45 AMS&amp;P US Services PMIAug F55.410:00 AMISM Services IndexAug50.550.111:30 AMFed's Williams Speaks on Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy7:00 PMFed's Goolsbee Appears in a Moderated Q&amp;A
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

Productivity and costs. We estimate 2Q productivity revises up to \(3.2\%\) from \(2.4\%\) following upward revision to 2Q GDP and some downward revision to 2Q labor input. Unit labor cost is trimmed similarly, to \(0.9\%\) from \(1.6\%\) . Both follow much less favorable readings in 1Q: In 1Q, GDP and productivity looked much weaker because of the flood of imports; in 2Q, both swung upwards as imports reversed.

New jobless claims remain low. Continuing claims rose in May and June but appear to have stabilized since then. The pattern in the two is consistent with no- faster layoffs but a slightly slower hiring rate.

Friday 05 SeptDataPeriodForecastConsensusPrev8:30 AMChange in Nonfarm PayrollsAug7080738:30 AMChange in Private PayrollsAug8075838:30 AMAverage Hourly Earnings m/mAug0.30.30.38:30 AMAverage Weekly Hours All EmployeesAug34.334.334.38:30 AMUnemployment RateAug4.24.34.28:30 AMLabor Force Participation RateAug62.2
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

Employment situation. Our forecasts of a 70k rise in payrolls and 80k rise in private payrolls are very similar to July payrolls: a slowing from earlier in the year, but not the sharp deceleration that June and May now show. The unemployment rate last month was \(4.2\%\) but right on the cusp of \(4.3\%\) . We think it sticks at \(4.2\%\) : breakeven have been falling; and we expect some further downward pressure on participation rates. Average hourly earnings rise on trend, and we expect no change in the workweek.
Exhibit 20: Sep 1-Sep 12

We revised our potential outcomes for the US Economy on August 29, 2025. For more detail, see The Fed shifts to risk management cuts.
